abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Highway Project in Nepal was
            achieved. Delays associated with the performance of other
            aid agencies in providing information and in implementation
            of their components is a significant feature of this project
            and indicates that the International Development Association
            (IDA) could have been more fully involved in all aspects of
            project preparation and implementation. The two main lesson
            from this project is that longer lead times for procurement
            and other vital actions should be allowed for than is
            customary in the sector. The two main problems identified in
            project formulation were: The inclusion of a main highway
            link at the last moment, without sufficient preparation, and
            analysis, and entrusting implementation to an ill-prepared
            Department of Roads (DOR). The lack of direct IDA control
            over the mechanics training component and technical
            assistance for maintenance activities led to delays and less
            than satisfactory performance. Although completion of most
            components of the Project and disbursements of the credit
            were delayed by about two years, the project's overall
            objectives as identified at appraisal were generally realized.

docna.cdata!:
Nepal - Second Highway Project : Credit 0730
            - Development Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Nepal - Second Highway Project :
            Credit 0730 - Development Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The project provides for: (a)
            construction, generally on an existing ailgnment, of a 50-km
            feeder road, together with improvements to connecting local
            roads; (b) procurement of construction equipment for use by
            the feeder road construction contractors; (c) upgrading, on
            the existing alignment, of a 17.5 km mountainous section of
            the main Katmandu-Indian border road; (d) road maintenance
            equipment, spares, two workshops and facilities in support
            of a nationwide Five-Year Road Maintenance Program; (e)
            consulting services for: (i) feasibility studies, detailed
            engineering and assistance in construction supervision for
            the feeder road; (ii) feasibility studies of the remaining
            190 km section of the East-West Highway; and (iii) technical
            investigation assistance; (f) training of construction and
            maintenance equipment mechanics.
